Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Supervised Exercise Versus Standard Care Following Lower Limb Revascularisation in Peripheral Arterial Disease

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to supervised exercise or standard care.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included 376 PAD patients, aged 18 and older, post-successful revascularisation.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to supervised exercise or standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the impact of supervised exercise versus standard care after lower limb revascularisation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was maximum walking distance (MWD) on a treadmill, assessed over six weeks to five years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with concealed allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 376 participants were randomised: 189 to the exercise group and 187 to standard care.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 89 in the exercise group and 108 in standard care, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Exercise showed no significant improvement in MWD from baseline (MD 159.47 m, 95% CI -36.43 to 355.38). However, exercise may improve absolute MWD at follow-up (MD 301.89 m, 95% CI 138.13 to 465.65).
